PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:
A third-party conducts a safety audit at the Amber Wave facility on a bi-annual basis. Amber Wave takes the third-party audit findings very seriously and attempts to implement all recommended changes on a timely basis. At the time of this RMP resubmission, Amber Wave has no planned changes to improve safety.

- therefore a release at the loadout area could be ceased within minutes by manual overrides. The loadout area also has a catchment basin with underground piping to secondary containment of the tank farm. For this scenario, passive and active mitigation was not considered, as the mitigation strategies currently in place would not contain a vapor cloud fire. RMP Comp was used to determine the alternative distance to end point; the model results were 0.1 miles and are provided as part of this documentation. Population and public receptor information was obtained using Circular Area Profiling System (CAPS) and Google Earth. No environmental receptors are affected by an alternative release of denaturant.

The Amber Wave facility qualifies as a Program 3 for the flammable mixture (denaturant) due to the close proximity of public receptors, and therefore, Program Safety Management has been completed for this facility.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:
Please review the first section of this Executive Summary for the general accidental release prevention program information. 

Amber Wave's maintenance department performs regular preventative maintenance inspections, as required by the manufacturer's recommendations and/or State and Federal regulations. Monthly visual inspections are performed and quarterly leak detection monitoring is performed and reports per KDHE requirements.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:
There have been no reportable accidents associated with the RMP covered process at the Amber Wave facility.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:
Amber Wave has several safety programs in place at the facility that incorporate actions taken by Amber Wave if a scenario should occur, including a Health and Safety. Amber Wave responds by calling the local authorities and has several spill response kits onsite. As mentioned, an Industrial SWPPP, SPCC and FRP have been prepared and implemented in accordance with applicable regulato

DESCRIPTION OF STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES:
Amber Wave consists of a wheat gluten plant and a co-located ethanol plant, located in Phillipsburg, Phillips County, Kansas. The facility operates 24 hours per day, 7 days per week for the purpose of manufacturing a high-quality food ingredient and fuel grade ethanol from wheat. The regulated substance stored at the facility is a flammable mixture - natural gasoline (denaturant).

WORST CASE AND ALTERNATIVE CASE SCENARIOS:
Worst Case Scenario:

1. Flammable Mixture (Denaturant): The flammable mixture stored onsite is natural gasoline, typically referred to as denaturant. Natural gasoline is used onsite to denature ethanol prior to shipment offsite.
Denaturant is stored in a steel tank in the facility tank farm. The tank is located in a diked containment structure that contains an impermeable liner with gravel overlay. A worst case SDS was used to determine RMP applicability. The worst case scenario used is the release of the entire contents of the denaturant tank, causing a vapor cloud explosion. RMP Comp was used to determine the worst case distance to endpoint; the model results were 0.7 mile radius and are provided as part of this documentation. Population and public receptor information was obtained using Circular Area Profiling System (CAPS) and Google Earth. A tributary to Deer Creek is located within the worst-case distance to endpoint for denaturant.

Alternative Scenario:
Flammable Mixture (Denaturant): The alternative scenario used for the flammable mixture is the release of natural gasoline due to a tanker truck loadout spill, causing a vapor cloud fire. The endpoint used was an over pressurization of 1 PSI, a worst case option. Denaturant deliveries at the facility typically occur during normal business hours with a facility staff member overseeing loadout operations

RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
Summit Sustainable Ingredients, LLC dba Amber Wave

This RMP resubmission is being submitted to reflect the addition of a wheat gluten plant which will allow the ethanol plant to utilize wheat slurry instead of corn as the feedstock.

ACCIDENTIAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES:
Summit Sustainable Ingredients dba Amber Wave (Amber Wave) has an ongoing commitment to the health and safety of onsite employees and the surrounding community. This commitment is demonstrated in the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training for the proper operation and maintenance of plant equipment and preventative maintenance programs.

Amber Wave has emergency policies in place that are addressed in the facility's Health and Safety Plan; Industrial Storm Water Pollution Prevention Plan (SWPPP); Spill Prevention, Controls, and Countermeasures Plan (SPCC); Facility Response Plan (FRP); that outline procedures for how Amber Wave handles spills. Most of the listed Plans require a minimum of annual training in order to keep employees educated on procedures in place at the facility. All new employees are required to undergo training on how Amber Wave responds to emergencies prior to initiating responsibilities onsite. These Plans also detail best management practice in place at the facility, i.e. good housekeeping, prompt routine equipment maintenance and inspections.

Amber Wave’s policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, plant personnel will contain the release as necessary.

The primary emergency coordinator for Amber Wave is Vicki Korobka, Commodities / Environmental of Amber Wave. Her work and 24-hour emergency response telephone numbers are provided in the Registration Section of this document. The following individuals (with associated work and 24-hour emergency response telephone numbers) are below:
